conversation.content: So here we are, after three years of your blog posts calling me everything from a corporate shill to, what was it, 'the embodiment of legal corruption.' [dry chuckle]
[defensive] Look, I stand by what I wrote about your defense of those pharmaceutical companies, but that's not why I'm here right now.
No, you're here because Senator Walsh is suing you for two million dollars and suddenly you need the very legal expertise you've spent years undermining.
I didn't defame anyone, I reported facts about his campaign finances that mainstream media was too scared to touch. [exhales] The truth shouldn't need a defense lawyer.
[measured] The truth is an absolute defense against defamation, yes, but you need proof, documentation, sources willing to testify, not just passionate blog posts and anonymous tips.
Which is why I'm swallowing my pride and sitting in your office right now, asking for help from someone whose entire career represents what I hate about the system.
[leaning forward] Let me be clear about something—I've read every single article you've written about me, and while your facts were often wrong, your passion was always genuine.
[surprised] You actually read them? I figured you had assistants filter that stuff out or, I don't know, just ignored the noise entirely.
Every word, and you know what's interesting? Your piece on the Morrison case actually helped me see a blind spot in my own argument. [pause] Cost me the case, but made me better.
[quietly] I didn't know that.
The senator's legal team is aggressive and well-funded, so if we're doing this, I need complete transparency about your sources, even the ones you've protected.
[firmly] Some of those people risked their careers to expose corruption, and I won't betray them just to save myself from a lawsuit.
[nodding slowly] Then we do this the hard way.
[uncertain] Meaning what exactly? Because I've got about twelve thousand in savings and a blog that barely breaks even on ad revenue.
[practical tone] Meaning we build your defense using only public records and documented evidence, which takes longer but protects your sources. My fee is contingent on winning.
[stunned] Why would you take this case on contingency when you know I've spent years trying to destroy your reputation?
[thoughtfully] Because sometimes the best critics make the most important points, and frankly, someone needs to defend the people who keep us lawyers honest. [slight smile]
[struggling] This is really hard for me to say, but thank you, and I'm sorry for calling you a soulless parasite in that June article.
[wry laugh] Oh, that wasn't even your harshest review.
[relieved exhale] So we're really doing this? You're going to represent someone who fundamentally opposes everything about how you practice law?
